bibl.title: Letter from John J. Moran to George A. Kellogg, October 25, 1941

div1.p: Moran apologizes to Kellogg for not writing and writes that he has not yet received copies of the Cornwell painting.

div1.head: Letter from John J. Moran to George A. Kellogg, October 25, 1941
div1.opener:
C O P Y
October 25, 1941
George A Kellogg, Esq.,
257 Cornelison Avenue
Jersey City, N.Y.
Dear Mr. Kellogg:
div1.p:
You will, and with good reason, have been
thinking that I am a most ungrateful specimen of the land of
my birth, the Emerald Isle and, if I may be pardoned for say-
ing so, one of the most hospitable little islands on the face
of the globe. Alas and alack, in my neglect to acknowledge
my appreciation of the honor accorded me by the House of Wyeth
and your very good self, I am afraid I have forfeited my rights
to the traditional gratefulness inherent in the sons of Erin.
I hope not, however, since down deep in my heart I sincerely
appreciate the honor which the Dean Cornwell painting, “THE
CONQUERORS OF YELLOW FEVER” confer on my humble self. I want
you to know this and I trust you will not think me ungrateful.

The truth of the matter is that, what with the
necessity of earning an honest living, which I have tried to do
since the tender age of nine, my spare time is extremely limited.
Since the passage of the ACT of February 28, 1929, according
Congressional recognition to all those who took part in the
Walter Reed yellow fever experiments, my spare time has never
sufficed to properly reply to the correspondence I have received
from every section of the United States. Also, in my effort
and desire to have the parts played by Reed and Finlay accepted
on a solid basis by Cubans and Americans alike, I have written
reams and reams of material, tediously drummed out on a machine
with my two index fingers. Being herein Cuba, away from Home
Office supervision, managing this Cuban subsidiary of Sun Oil
Company, my duties to my employer could not be neglected. I
am not - and please do not think so - trying to establish an
alibi for my failure to reply, in the spirit which it was in-
cumbent upon me to do, to your many missives to me in the past
several months. I have been never able to school myself to the
writing of short letters. Now, at 66, it is too late to even try.

I have not received the art prints announced
in your letter dated July 24th. Most likely they are not ready
as yet. I just wonder how many you would be kind enough to
spare me for a few of my very dear friends. As soon as I re-
ceive one of the large ones from you I have arranged to have a
copy painted for me by a Rumanian refugee lady residing in Cuba
at the present. Her work is pronounced excellent by critics
(amateur) here.
With my sincere personal regards, I remain
div1.closer:
Yours sincerely JOHN J. MORAN c/o Cia. Sunoco de Cuba, S.A.,
Avenida Menocal Nos 455-457,
Havana, Cuba
